title: Libral standard
text:
The libral standard compares the weight of <a href="coin">coin</a>s to the bronze "<a href="as%20%28Roman%20coin%29">as</a>", which originally weighed one <a href="Ancient%20Roman%20units%20of%20measurement">Roman pound</a>, but decreased over time to 1/2 pound (the semi-libral standard). It is often used in discussions of ancient cast coinage of central Italy, especially <a href="Etruscan%20coins">Etruscan coins</a> and <a href="Roman%20Republican%20coinage">Roman Republican coinage</a>. The adjective "libral" is related to "libra", the <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Ancient Roman</a> unit of weight, and is not related to the word "<a href="wiktionary%3ALiberal">liberal</a>".
The libral standard began with the era of the so-called <a href="aes%20grave">aes grave</a> (heavy bronze) cast coinage of Rome, from circa 280 BC, where one "as" weighed one Roman pound (<a href="Ancient%20Roman%20units%20of%20measurement">libra</a>), or twelve Roman ounces (<a href="Ancient%20Roman%20units%20of%20measurement">unciae</a>). This changed when the weight of the aes grave was decreased to approximately 10 unciae (the "light libral standard") circa 265-217 BC, remaining at that level until about 217 BC. It then suddenly fell to 6 unciae (the "semi-libral standard") around the start of the second Punic war in about 217 BC, before finally falling still further until about 141 BC.
The libral/semi-libral standards were followed by the triental standards and the sextantal standard.
Many Greek city states (colonies) were founded on the Italian peninsula and Sicily during this time period; these are collectively referred to as <a href="Magna%20Graecia">Magna Graecia</a>. The coinage of those city-states is more closely related to the rest of the ancient Greek world (which included many colonies along the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> and <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> coasts), and generally has no relationship to the Etruscan/Roman units.
